cat_calorie_calculator.title: Cat Calorie Calculator
cat_calorie_calculator.description: Calculate your cat's daily calorie needs.
cat_calorie_calculator.tooltip_weight: Enter your cat's weight in kilograms
cat_calorie_calculator.tooltip_condition: Is your cat underweight, normal, or overweight?
cat_calorie_calculator.tooltip_neutered: Check if your cat is neutered or spayed
cat_calorie_calculator.tip_protein: Cats are obligate carnivores, they need animal protein
cat_calorie_calculator.tip_taurine: Ensure taurine is in the diet
cat_calorie_calculator.tip_vet: Consult a vet for an ideal diet
cat_calorie_calculator.info_description: Cats have specific dietary requirements. Their calorie needs depend on their weight, activity level, and neuter status.
cat_calorie_calculator.empty_state: Enter your cat's details to calculate calorie needs
cat_calorie_calculator.footer_note: These are estimates. Individual needs may vary.
tips: Cats are obligate carnivores, they need animal protein
Ensure taurine is in the diet
Consult a vet for an ideal diet

howItWorks.title: How Cat Calorie Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: RER = 70 × (body weight in kg)^0.75, then multiply by activity factor
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines your cat's daily energy needs based on weight, activity level, body condition, and neuter status using the Resting Energy Requirement formula.
steps: Enter your cat's weight in kilograms
Select the activity level that best describes your cat
Choose the body condition score
Indicate if your cat is neutered or spayed
View daily calorie and macronutrient recommendations

useCases: Managing your cat's weight through proper portion control
Planning diet for weight loss or weight gain
Adjusting calories for different activity levels
Understanding nutritional needs after neutering
seoTips: Neutered cats need 20-30% fewer calories
Measure food portions accurately with a kitchen scale
Divide daily calories across multiple small meals
Account for treats in the daily calorie budget
Reassess calorie needs as cats age
commonMistakes: Free-feeding cats without measuring portions
Not reducing calories after neutering
Ignoring treat calories in daily totals
Using the same calories for all life stages

faqs.question: How many calories does an average cat need?
faqs.answer: An average 4kg adult cat needs about 200-250 calories per day. This varies based on activity level, age, and whether the cat is neutered.

faqs.question: Should I reduce calories for a neutered cat?
faqs.answer: Yes, neutered cats have lower metabolic rates and need 20-30% fewer calories to maintain a healthy weight.

faqs.question: How do I know if my cat is overweight?
faqs.answer: You should be able to feel your cat's ribs easily without pressing hard. From above, your cat should have a visible waist. Consult your vet for a body condition assessment.

faqs.question: What percentage of calories should come from protein?
faqs.answer: Cats are obligate carnivores and need 30-45% of their calories from protein. Animal-based proteins are essential for their health.

faqs.question: Do indoor cats need fewer calories?
faqs.answer: Generally yes. Indoor cats are typically less active and may need 10-20% fewer calories than outdoor cats to prevent weight gain.

cat_food_calculator.title: Cat Food Calculator
cat_food_calculator.description: Calculate the right amount of food for your cat.
cat_food_calculator.tooltip_weight: Enter your cat's weight in kilograms
cat_food_calculator.empty_state: Enter your cat's details to calculate feeding amount

howItWorks.title: How Cat Food Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Daily food amount based on weight, activity, age, and food type caloric density
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines the optimal daily food portion for your cat based on their specific needs and the type of food you're feeding.
steps: Enter your cat's current weight
Select their activity level
Choose their life stage (kitten, adult, senior)
Select the type of food (dry, wet, or raw)
View daily, weekly, and monthly feeding amounts

useCases: Determining proper portion sizes for your cat
Planning food purchases and budgeting
Transitioning between different food types
Managing weight through controlled feeding
seoTips: Wet food has fewer calories per gram than dry food
Kittens need more frequent meals than adult cats
Measure food with a scale for accuracy
Adjust portions based on weight changes
Senior cats may need smaller, more frequent meals
commonMistakes: Using volume instead of weight to measure food
Not adjusting portions when switching food types
Overfeeding treats on top of regular meals
Feeding adult food to kittens or kitten food to seniors

faqs.question: How often should I feed my cat?
faqs.answer: Adult cats do well with 2-3 meals per day. Kittens need 3-4 smaller meals. Some cats prefer grazing, but measured portions help prevent obesity.

faqs.question: Is wet food better than dry food?
faqs.answer: Both have benefits. Wet food provides hydration and is lower in calories. Dry food is convenient and helps dental health. Many vets recommend a combination.

faqs.question: How do I switch my cat to a new food?
faqs.answer: Transition gradually over 7-10 days, mixing increasing amounts of new food with decreasing amounts of old food to prevent digestive upset.

faqs.question: Should kittens eat different amounts?
faqs.answer: Yes, kittens have higher caloric needs relative to their weight due to rapid growth. They need kitten-specific food with higher protein and calories.

faqs.question: Why is my cat always hungry?
faqs.answer: This could indicate the portions are too small, the food lacks nutrients, or there may be health issues. Consult your vet if hunger seems excessive.

howItWorks.title: How Dog Calorie Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: RER = 70 × (body weight in kg)^0.75, then multiply by activity and condition factors
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines daily caloric needs using the Resting Energy Requirement formula, adjusted for activity level, body condition, and neuter status.
steps: Enter your dog's weight in kilograms
Select the activity level that matches your dog
Choose the current body condition
Indicate if your dog is neutered or spayed
View daily calorie and macronutrient recommendations

useCases: Managing your dog's weight through proper feeding
Planning diet for weight loss or muscle gain
Adjusting calories for working or athletic dogs
Understanding nutritional needs for different activity levels
seoTips: Working dogs may need 2-3 times the calories of sedentary dogs
Neutered dogs typically need 25-30% fewer calories
Puppies need more calories per pound than adults
Adjust calories seasonally for outdoor dogs
Senior dogs often need fewer calories but more protein
commonMistakes: Using human food guidelines for dog nutrition
Not adjusting calories after neutering
Overestimating activity level
Forgetting to include treats in calorie count

faqs.question: How many calories does my dog need per day?
faqs.answer: It varies widely. A 10kg moderately active dog needs about 500-600 calories, while a 30kg active dog might need 1500-1800. Use the calculator for personalized results.

faqs.question: Should I reduce calories for a neutered dog?
faqs.answer: Yes, neutering reduces metabolic rate by 25-30%. Reduce calories accordingly to prevent weight gain.

faqs.question: How do activity levels affect calorie needs?
faqs.answer: Sedentary dogs need baseline RER, moderately active need 1.5-2x RER, and working/sporting dogs may need 2-3x RER or more.

faqs.question: What's the best protein ratio for dogs?
faqs.answer: Most dogs do well with 18-25% protein. Active and working dogs benefit from 25-30%. Puppies and nursing dogs need even higher protein levels.

faqs.question: Do large breed puppies need different calories?
faqs.answer: Yes, large breed puppies should be fed for controlled growth to prevent joint problems. Don't overfeed to speed up growth.

faqs.answer: It varies widely. A 10kg moderately active dog needs about 500-600 calories, while a 30kg active dog might need 1500-1800. Use the calculator for personalized results.

faqs.question: Should I reduce calories for a neutered dog?

howItWorks.title: How Dog Food Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Daily food = (Caloric needs / Food caloric density) adjusted for food type
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines optimal daily food portions based on your dog's weight, activity level, life stage, and the type of food you're feeding.
steps: Enter your dog's current weight
Select their activity level
Choose their life stage (puppy, adult, senior)
Select the type of food (dry, wet, or raw)
View daily, weekly, and monthly feeding amounts

useCases: Determining proper portion sizes for your dog
Planning food purchases and budgeting
Transitioning puppies to adult food
Managing weight through controlled portions
seoTips: Puppies need 3-4 meals daily, adults need 2
Dry food is more calorie-dense than wet food
Large breed puppies need specific growth formulas
Measure food by weight, not volume
Adjust portions based on body condition changes
commonMistakes: Using measuring cups instead of scales
Feeding puppies adult food
Not adjusting for treats given throughout the day
Free-feeding leading to obesity

faqs.question: How often should I feed my dog?
faqs.answer: Puppies under 6 months need 3-4 meals daily. Adult dogs do well with 2 meals per day. Some owners prefer once daily feeding for adults.

faqs.question: Should I feed wet or dry food?
faqs.answer: Both are nutritionally complete. Dry food is convenient and good for dental health. Wet food provides hydration. Many owners use a combination.

faqs.question: How do I transition to new food?
faqs.answer: Gradually mix new food with old over 7-10 days, increasing the new food proportion daily. This prevents digestive upset.

faqs.question: Why is my dog always hungry?
faqs.answer: Some dogs are food-motivated regardless of portion. If your dog maintains a healthy weight, the portions are likely correct. Consult your vet if concerned.

faqs.question: Do puppies need different amounts?
faqs.answer: Yes, puppies need more food relative to their body weight due to rapid growth. Large breed puppies need controlled portions to prevent joint issues.

horse_feed_calculator.description: Calculate correct horse feeding amounts accurately.
horse_feed_calculator.tooltip_weight: Enter your horse's weight in kilograms
horse_feed_calculator.empty_state: Enter horse details to calculate feeding amount
horse_feed_calculator.footer_note: These are estimates. Individual needs may vary.
tips: Hay should be the basis of the diet

howItWorks.title: How Horse Feed Calculator Works
howItWorks.formula: Daily feed = 1.5-3% of body weight depending on work level
howItWorks.explanation: This calculator determines optimal daily feed amounts based on horse weight and work level, balancing hay, grain, and supplements for nutritional needs.
steps: Enter your horse's weight in kilograms
Select the work level (maintenance to heavy work)
Choose the feed type (hay only, mixed, or performance)
View daily hay, grain, and water recommendations

useCases: Planning daily feeding schedules for horses
Budgeting feed costs for horse ownership
Adjusting nutrition for working or competition horses
Managing weight for overweight or underweight horses
seoTips: Horses need 1.5-2% of body weight in forage daily minimum
Work level significantly affects grain requirements
Quality hay can reduce grain needs
Divide daily feed into multiple small meals
Water intake averages 5-10 gallons per day
commonMistakes: Overfeeding grain relative to forage
Not adjusting feed for seasonal work changes
Sudden diet changes causing colic
Ignoring body condition when setting portions

faqs.question: How much hay does a horse need daily?
faqs.answer: A horse needs a minimum of 1.5-2% of body weight in forage. A 500kg horse needs at least 7.5-10kg of hay daily as a foundation.

faqs.question: When should I add grain to the diet?
faqs.answer: Add grain when hay alone cannot meet energy needs, typically for horses in moderate to heavy work, growing horses, or lactating mares.

faqs.question: How much water does a horse need?
faqs.answer: Horses drink 20-40 liters (5-10 gallons) daily. This increases with work, hot weather, and lactation.

faqs.question: How many times a day should I feed?
faqs.answer: Divide daily feed into 2-3 meals minimum. Horses are designed to eat frequently, so more small meals are better for digestion.

faqs.question: Should I use a complete feed?
faqs.answer: Complete feeds are convenient but hay should still be offered for dental health and digestive function unless a horse cannot chew properly.
